message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of light vaginal bleeding, lower abdominal discomfort, and an enlarged uterus with adnexal masses suggests a possible ectopic pregnancy or molar pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and determine the location of the pregnancy. Chorionic villus sampling is not indicated at this point in the workup. Thyroid function tests and fetal Doppler ultrasound are not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with vaginal bleeding and adnexal masses, which suggests a possible ectopic pregnancy or a molar pregnancy. The next appropriate step in management is a transvaginal ultrasound to determine the location of the pregnancy and assess for any complications. Chorionic villus sampling, thyroid function tests, and fetal Doppler ultrasound are not indicated as the primary management strategies for this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with vaginal bleeding and an enlarged uterus with adnexal masses. These findings are suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy or a molar pregnancy. A transvaginal ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis and determine the location of the pregnancy. Chorionic villus sampling and thyroid function tests are not necessary at this point. Fetal Doppler ultrasound is also not necessary as the initial concern is to determine the location of the pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage, and a transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step to evaluate the pregnancy and confirm the diagnosis. Chorionic villus sampling, thyroid function tests, and fetal Doppler ultrasound are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage, and the enlarged uterus and adnexal masses suggest a molar pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment options. Chorionic villus sampling, thyroid function tests, and fetal Doppler ultrasound are not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible ectopic pregnancy or molar pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound can identify the location of the gestational sac and determine if there is a viable pregnancy. Chorionic villus sampling, thyroid function tests, and fetal Doppler ultrasound are not indicated at this point.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort, and the pelvic examination suggests an enlarged uterus and bilateral adnexal masses. Combined with the high serum β-hCG concentration, this suggests the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy or a molar pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound can help differentiate between these possibilities and guide further management. The other options are not appropriate at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with vaginal bleeding and adnexal masses, which suggests an ectopic pregnancy. The next step in management should be a transvaginal ultrasound to confirm the location of the pregnancy. Chorionic villus sampling is not indicated at this time. Thyroid function tests are not relevant to the current presentation. Fetal Doppler ultrasound would not be useful in this case, as the pregnancy is not intrauterine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal discomfort at 14 weeks' gestation with an enlarged uterus and bilateral adnexal masses. These findings suggest a molar pregnancy or a multiple gestation. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound to evaluate the pregnancy and determine the cause of the vaginal bleeding. Chorionic villus sampling, thyroid function tests, and fetal Doppler ultrasound are not indicated at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms and findings suggestive of a possible molar pregnancy or multiple gestations. Transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the status of the pregnancy. Chorionic villus sampling and fetal Doppler ultrasound may be considered later but are not the initial diagnostic tests for this presentation. Thyroid function tests are not indicated in this scenario.
